bestBHT.bht: The use of the term dogs in reference to the woman does not indicate any contempt; rather, it refers to tame and familiar household dogs. By calling the Gentiles little dogs who belong to their masters, Jesus is speaking honorably of them. This interaction serves as a test of the woman's faith and serves to emphasize the rejection of the Jews who refuse the blessings intended for them but are freely offered to those who seek them fervently.

Henry Alford: No contempt is indicated by the diminutive, still less any allusion to the daughter of the woman.
The word is commonly used of tame dogs, as diminutives frequently express familiarity.
Marvin Vincent: Children's [των τεκνων]. Bengel observes that while Christ spoke severely to the Jews, he spoke honorably of them to those without.
Their masters. The children are the masters of the little dogs.
John Calvin: To make the meaning plain to us, it must be understood that the appellation of the children’s bread is here given, not to the gifts of God of whatever description, but only to those which were bestowed in a peculiar manner on Abraham and his posterity.
By using the word throw, Christ intimates that what is taken from the Church of God and given to heathens is not well bestowed.

His chief design was, to make trial of the woman’s faith; but he also pointed out the dreadful vengeance that would overtake the Jews, who rejected an inestimable benefit which was freely offered to them, and which they refused to those who sought it with warmth and earnestness.
Philip Schaff: The reply is not harsh, nor is it a refusal... It calls forth the woman’s faith, and convinces the disciples that it is ‘proper’ to bless this heathen woman.
All present understood this as referring to the blessings provided for the Jews.
A reference to the large savage dogs so common in the East, would be very contemptuous; household dogs are meant; a sense the woman skilfully used.
John Gill: By 'the children', are meant the Jews, to whom the adoption belonged; who, as a nation and people, were the children of God in a large sense.
By 'the bread'...is meant the external ministry of the word, and the miracles of Christ wrought among them.
By 'the dogs' are designed the Gentiles, so called by the Jews in a way of contempt, because of their ignorance, idolatry, and impurity.

bhtAttempts.bht: The woman in this passage is not being belittled in any way, as the term dogs is commonly used to refer to tame and familiar household dogs. Jesus is speaking honorably of the Gentiles, represented by the little dogs who belong to their masters, the children. This interaction serves to test the woman's faith, and also to highlight the rejection of the Jews who refuse the blessings that were intended for them, but are freely offered to those who seek them with earnestness.

The use of the term dogs in reference to the woman does not indicate any contempt; rather, it refers to tame and familiar household dogs. By calling the Gentiles little dogs who belong to their masters, Jesus is speaking honorably of them. This interaction serves as a test of the woman's faith and serves to emphasize the rejection of the Jews who refuse the blessings intended for them but are freely offered to those who seek them fervently.

The woman is not being belittled as the term dogs here refers to tame and familiar household dogs. Jesus speaks honorably of the Gentiles, represented by the little dogs who belong to their masters, the children. This interaction tests the woman's faith and highlights the rejection of the Jews who refuse the blessings meant for them but are freely offered to those who earnestly seek them. It is not a harsh reply but calls forth the woman's faith and convinces the disciples that it is appropriate to bless this Gentile woman.

This interaction tests the woman's faith and highlights the rejection of the Jews who refuse the blessings meant for them but are freely offered to those who earnestly seek them.

Jesus speaks honorably of the Gentiles, who are represented by the little dogs belonging to their masters, the children.
